newsitem.title: KUWAIT: $33 mln to expand Kuwait mobile phone capacity.
newsitem.headline: $33 mln to expand Kuwait mobile phone capacity.

text.p: Kuwait has allocated 10 million dinars ($33 million) to add capacity to its mobile telephone system as part of a plan to privatise the sector, an official was quoted on Wednesday as saying.

Communications ministry assisstant undersecretary for services, Faisal al-Omar, said the funds would be spent "on installing equipment to widen the system to absorb the new company," al-Qabas newspaper reported.

Earlier in April, the head of the state Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA) Ali al-Badr told Reuters that a second mobile telephones firm would be launched in November, ending a monopoly by Mobile Telephone Company (MTC) to facilite the privatisation of the sector.
Al-Omar said that launching the second firm was a priority.
The state's shedding of shares in MTC must be preceded by ending its monopoly of the local market, officials said.
Badr said that the state, represented by its investment arm KIA, holds some 49 percent of MTC's shares and will have a stake of between 25 percent and 40 percent in the new firm.
KIA has sold stakes in 22 listed and unlisted firms since the launch of the first phase of the privatisation programme in September 1994 for 740 million dinars.
"KIA shares in 11 yet to be privatised main companies, firms which we own more than 25 percent in, and a few minor holdings are worth another one billion dinars," he added.
